captions.text:
Austrian physicist Erwin Schrödinger is
one of the founders of quantum mechanics,

but he's most famous for something he
never actually did:
a thought experiment involving a cat.

He imagined taking a cat and
placing it in a sealed box

with a device that had a 50% chance
of killing the cat in the next hour.

At the end of that hour, he asked,
"What is the state of the cat?"

Common sense suggests that the cat
is either alive or dead,

but Schrödinger pointed out that according
to quantum physics,

at the instant before the box is opened,
the cat is equal parts alive and dead,
at the same time.

It's only when the box is opened
that we see a single definite state.

Until then, the cat is 
a blur of probability,
half one thing and half the other.

This seems absurd, 
which was Schrödinger's point.

He found quantum physics so 
philosophically disturbing,

that he abandoned the theory
he had helped make
and turned to writing about biology.

As absurd as it may seem, though,
Schrödinger's cat is very real.
In fact, it's essential.

If it weren't possible for quantum objects
to be in two states at once,

the computer you're using to watch this
couldn't exist.

The quantum phenomenon of 
superposition

is a consequence of the dual
particle and wave nature of everything.

In order for an object to have
a wavelength,
it must extend over some region of space,

which means it occupies many positions
at the same time.

The wavelength of an object limited
to a small region of space
can't be perfectly defined, though.

So it exists in many different wavelengths
at the same time.

We don't see these wave properties
for everyday objects

because the wavelength decreases
as the momentum increases.
And a cat is relatively big and heavy.

If we took a single atom and blew
it up to the size of the Solar System,

the wavelength of a cat 
running from a physicist

would be as small as an atom 
within that Solar System.

That's far too small to detect, so we'll
never see wave behavior from a cat.
A tiny particle, like an electron, though,

can show dramatic evidence
of its dual nature.

If we shoot electrons one at a time at a
set of two narrow slits cut in a barrier,

each electron on the far side is detected
at a single place at a specific instant,
like a particle.

But if you repeat this 
experiment many times,

keeping track of all the 
individual detections,

you'll see them trace out a pattern that's
characteristic of wave behavior:

a set of stripes - regions with many
electrons

separated by regions
where there are none at all.

Block one of the slits 
and the stripes go away.

This shows that the pattern is a result of
each electron going through both slits
at the same time.

A single electron isn't choosing 
to go left or right
but left and right simultaneously.

This superposition of states also leads
to modern technology.

An electron near the nucleus of an atom
exists in a spread out, wave-like orbit.
Bring two atoms close together,

and the electrons don't need to 
choose just one atom
but are shared between them.
This is how some chemical bonds form.

An electron in a molecule isn't on
just atom A or atom B, but A+ B.

As you add more atoms,
the electrons spread out more,

shared between vast numbers of atoms
at the same time.

The electrons in a solid aren't 
bound to a particular atom

but shared among all of them,
extending over a large range of space.
This gigantic superposition of states

determines the ways electrons move
through the material,

whether it's a conductor or an insulator
or a semiconductor.

Understanding how electrons are shared
among atoms

allows us to precisely control the
properties of semiconductor materials,
like silicon.

Combining different semiconductors
in the right way

allows us to make transistors 
on a tiny scale,
millions on a single computer chip.
Those chips and their spread out electrons

power the computer you're using to
watch this video.

An old joke says that the Internet 
exists to allow the sharing of cat videos.

At a very deep level, though,
the Internet owes its existance

to an Austrian physicist
and his imaginary cat.

title: Schrödinger's cat: A thought experiment in quantum mechanics - Chad Orzel

comments.text:
I never really understood why you need to open the box to determine if 
whether or not the cat is DOA. If you don't hear the cat moving inside the 
box for an extended period of time, then the cat is dead. With common 
sense, they are a lot of ways to determine the state of the cat without 
ever opening the box.﻿

Yes, "the observer affects the experiment" - everybody knows that. This 
principle aspect of quantum mechanics was discovered c. 1920 - about 100 
years ago. In this biocentric/anthropocentric universe, we are not only 
observers who affect the experiment, we are participants and co-creators.

comments.author: Zachary Henshaw

comments.text:
Shame on you TED Ed!!!

With explanations like this, no wonder people think Quantum Mechanics are 
confusing. This video confuses once an again wave functions with actual 
quantum objects. Wave functions are a mathematical tool used to describe 
quantum objects. The squared modulus of wave functions gives us the 
probability of finding an object in a given state/place/speed —that's the 
Copenhagen interpretation—; but the functions are not the actual objects. 
So, yes, those functions can overlap and take exotic shapes, meaning that 
an quantum object, f.ex. an electron, can have a certain probability of 
being here and also a probability of being there —of passing by one slit or 
the other—. That's as much as we can know, probabilities; but the actual 
electron is only at one place at a time!!! We just don't know which one, 
unless we measure it. And we can do that, no problem; no experiment 
measures electrons passing by the two slits at the same time.

The interference pattern in the screen shows up, not because the electron 
interferes with itself —like the video tries to fool us into believing—, 
but because each electron can take any of the probable paths. So, after 
throwing many electrons, each choosing it's own path, their landing spots 
in the screen displays the probability distribution dictated by the 
characteristics of the system —slits+electrons—. Just alike the added 
results of throwing for example three dice a bunch of times will distribute 
themselves according to the more and less likely combinations. So 10s and 
11s will show up way more often than 3s and 18s. Which value takes set of 
dice before you throw them? None? All? The question doesn't make much 
sense, right?. Before throwing it, the dice just have a probability of 
taking all values. We still don't know which one it will take; but the dice 
are still very solid and real and not fuzzy or confused. Only we are 
confused by our silly question... Same goes for electrons and any other 
quantum objects, until we thrown them, until make a measurement, we can 
only know there probabilities of being here or there, passing by this or 
that slit. Now, in practical terms, when we calculate stuff, we can only 
calculate and reach conclusion based on what we know, and we can know just 
probabilities and only give probabilistic conclusions. So, people often 
tend to confuse those probabilities with the actual objects and come up 
with preposterous interpretations such as the one in this video.

So no mystery here. Just the statistical effects showing as consequence of 
the knowledge limit imposed by the Uncertainty Principle. And, btw, there 
still will be diffraction after closing one of the slits! But that's 
another story...﻿

comments.author: luis enrique rodriguez otero

comments.text:
*El gato de Schrödinger: un experimento mental de mecánica cuántica 
explicado fácilmente*
# 
http://www.microsiervos.com/archivo/ciencia/el-gato-de-schrodinger-experimento-mental.html
El gato más famoso de la Física es el hilo conductor de esta breve historia 
animada divulgativa sobre mecánica cuántica, que pretende explicar el 
clásico experimento mental de Schrödinger de forma muy breve y enseñar 
algunas de sus connotaciones; por ejemplo que debido a ese gato puedes ver 
este vídeo en tu ordenador.

«En el experimento mental se toma un gato y se mete en una caja sellada. 
Junto a él hay un dispositivo [por ejemplo un medidior de radioactividad] 
que tiene un 50 por ciento de probabilidad de matar al gato en la siguiente 
hora. Al final de esa hora, la cuestión es: ¿cuál es el estado del gato?

El sentido común sugiere que el gato estará vivo o muerto. Pero Schrödinger 
señaló que según la física cuántica justo antes de abrir la caja el gato 
está al mismo tiempo vivo y muerto. Solo al abrir la caja veremos un estado 
bien definido.

Hasta el último momento el gato es una especie de probabilidad difusa, 
medio una cosa, medio la otra. Puede parecer absurdo, pero según la física 
cuántica es así. A Schrödinger todo esto le pareció tan filosóficamente 
inquietante que abandono la teoría que había ayudado a crear para dedicarse 
a la biología.»

Los átomos no son como los «sistemas solares» que se suelen dibujar, en los 
que los electrones dan vueltas alrededor del núcleo; tal y como se explica 
en el vídeo las propiedades de las partículas subatómicas son 
probabilísticas: al ser algo bastante contrario a nuestra intuición y 
experiencia cotidiana no podemos apreciarlo en toda su sutileza – algo que 
sí hace este experimento. Para mayor complicación, el hecho de que esos 
efectos –como puede ser peculiar comportamiento dual a modo de ondas y 
partículas, o la relación de indeterminación de Heisenberg– sean de una 
magnitud tan lejana a nuestra «escala humana» no hace sino complicar las 
cosas.

Pero pese a la dificultad de entender el mundo cuántico los seres humanos 
nos las hemos ingeniado para aprovechar sus propiedades y combinar átomos y 
moléculas en materiales semiconductores, con los que se construyen 
ordenadores y dispositivos electrónicos que utilizamos a diario. Como bien 
dice el vídeo, «es un irónico e interesante giro: que lo que se suele decir 
en broma de Internet, ‘que fue construida para ver vídeos de gatos’, se 
deba en parte a un famoso gato del que renegó hasta su creador».﻿
comments.author: carmen vargas

comments.text: Bonito vídeo para explicar el famoso "gato de Schröedinger" ;)﻿

Mundos paralelos? Es posible tener dos vidas simultáneamente en dos lugares 
diferentes y encontrarse con la paradoja de no poder interactuar con tu 
doble....Me resulta difícil asimilar algo así.
Quería comentaros si conocéis si este tema es tratado en el cine. Ya sé que 
la literatura sci-fi sí lo trata pero siempre recuerdo una película del 
director polaco Krzysztof Kieślowski : La doble vida de Verónica .Me viene 
a la cabeza, la teoría de cuerdas?
http://es.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_doble_vida_de_Ver%C3%B3nica Muy 
recomendable. 
Podría englobarse dentro del "multiverso" cuántico...? >_< Gracias.

comments.author: John Carter

comments.text:
Austrian physicist Erwin Schrödinger, one of the founders of quantum 
mechanics, posed this famous question: If you put a cat in a sealed box 
with a device that has a 50% chance of killing the cat in the next hour, 
what will be the state of the cat when that time is up? Chad Orzel 
investigates this thought experiment. ﻿

The cat must be a terrible example for the metaphor because a cat, nor any 
other living thing cannot be both dead and alive at the same time simply 
because you don't know whether or not it's still alive. It is either dead 
before you look in the box or alive before you look in the box. 

And I also remember reading that whenever we try to observe a particle, we 
always disturb it and tamper with the true measurement of it's velocity or 
position. But why does the fact that simply because we can't *truly* get a 
completely accurate measurement of a particle mean that the particle exists 
in two different states? We are just unable to know the complete current 
state (singular) of the particle due to humans not being omniscient. What 
leap in logic dictates that it should exist in two completely different 
states at the same time?﻿

i find schrödinger's cat such a badly chosen example for quantum states as 
the cat is of course a conscious life form and therefore is capable of 
observation just as humans are. in other words, there won't be any "sudden 
change" in the moment the box is opened by a human that observes/measures 
the state of the cat, as this measurement has already been taken place by

comments.author: Googelplus Sucksys

comments.text:
+Googelplus Sucksys
I said that it's a good approach to imagine it like that (being at both 
places the same time) but I insist that it's not accurate. When a particle 
is in superposition of being at two places, it means its wavefunction is 
spread at those two places. While being in superposition it behaves like 
it's at both places but as I said we can't gasp what's like being in 
superposition. It's out of our every-day experience. To say that the 
particle itself is at both places simultaneously is not accurate, because 
after all it's just a particle. It's the wavefunction of the particle that 
can be in both places at the same time.
comments.author: kostas2718

comments.text:
+Holly Lab When a superposition collapses into a certain state it remains 
in that state. But that doesn't mean that it can never be again in 
superposition.

For example, let's think the double split experiment. We observe an 
electron passing through a certain slit. That means we caused the 
superposition to collapse, because of the two possible outcome we observed 
one of them. But, if we put a secend layer of double slits between the 
first one and the detector, the same electron we'll be in superposition 
again, and we'll have the same results at the detector.

In the Schrodinger's cat experiment, if we open the box, we observe the 
system and cause the superposition to collapse. But if the cat is alive we 
can repeat the experiment and put the cat again in a superposition. If it's 
dead we can't repeat the experiment, because we can't bring the cat back to 
life, so there will be no superposition.
comments.author: kostas2718

comments.text: +Holly Lab The cat doesn't affect the experiment at all. It's relative!

existing at both A and B simultaneously and as you even essentially say

Schrodinger obviously wouldn’t even have made his argument against the 
absurdity of quantum mechanics if he didn’t believe quantum mechanics as we 
know it would actually apply in such a situation.

comments.author: Holly Lab

comments.text:
I 'd like to give a better explanation of the Schrodinger's cat experiment, 
because there seems to be a lot of misunderstanding. The great thing about 
ths thought experiment is that we got for the first time quantum mechanics' 
properties in our macroworld. First of all in order to understand the 
experiment you need to be familiar with the term 'superposition'.

Superposition is a state of a particle (or system) that includes all the 
possible 'minor states'. For example, let's say a particle is in 
superposition of being at point A and point B. If we observe the system, we 
are going to find the particle at point A or point B. It can't be both. But 
before the observation the particle was not only at A, not only at B, not 
both A and B at the same time, because it's just a particle, and of course 
not at neither of them, because then it wouldn't exist. We say it's in 
superposition of being at A and B, and we can't quite gasp what is like 
being in that sate, but a good approach is being at both places the same 
time. That's why you hear that in every pop-science video.

Now, back to Schrodinger's cat. The original thought experiment wasn't that 
simple. It included a trap inside the box which was triggered when the 
radioactive isotope stops emitting radiation. This is a quantum phenomenon, 
and obeys to the rules of quantum mechanics. So, at any given time the 
isotope is in superposition of emitting radiation and not to, as a result 
the trap is in superposition of being triggered and not to, and finally the 
cat is in superposition of being alive and being dead.

That doesn't mean that every system which we don't know its outcome, exists 
at all possible outcome at the same time before we do the observation. The 
only reason we say that the cat is both dead and alive is because it all 
started from a quantum phenomenon. This 'superposition state' exists only 
in the quantum world and that is what makes the difference between our 
every-day-world and the microworld (the world of tiny particles)

Hope I helped
comments.author: kostas2718

comments.text:
+Holly Lab the cat is a metaphor for a quantum particle. Of course the cat 
wouldn't do that.
comments.author: Justus B

comments.text:
+Shawn Ravenfire The cat’s box is idealized in the experiment. It’s not 
often explained in detail in videos but must be a very special “black box”. 
It must be big enough for the cat and the contraption, must open and close 
and while closed absolutely nothing may go out of the box or the 
superposition collapses or decoheres. Your apartment is not such a system: 
the air will observe your state and interact with the walls which will 
carry it out of your apartment and as such the chain will continue until 
everyone and everything on Earth has observed your alive/death state. 
Maintaining such a “black box” that basically may not interact with 
anything in its environment at all is obviously very difficult and which is 
why no one has done the experiment with a whole cat yet but superposition 
has been observed in macroscopic objects.

As for your thoughts on immortality if there’s even a slim chance that 
you’re going to survive to eternity then it will definitely happen because 
in quantum mechanics everything that can happen, happens.

Is there a slim chance that you may survive onto eternity? Difficult to 
say. Most of everything that happens on Earth is currently very definite 
outside of quantum mechanical experiments but in the early stages of 
Earth’s development or even the Big Bang there may have been times when the 
entire destiny of Earth depended on singular quantum events in which case 
there could be next to infinitely many Earth’s where indeed one of you 
survives onto immortality.

But that’s speculation.
comments.author: Googelplus Sucksys

comments.text:
+Googelplus Sucksys Okay, so let's say it's not a cat in a box exposed to 
radioactive material.  Suppose it's me in my apartment, who may or may not 
have died from something like a heart attack.  What I'm getting at is that 
if no one else comes in to find me, does that mean that I'm both dead and 
alive at the same time?  If so, then the "dead" me doesn't know it, so I 
would just seem from my own point of view that I'm always alive.  This 
seems to make sense, until you consider that this would be the case on any 
given day, which means that after something like a thousand years (assuming 
I was left alone in there all that time), I would have to have died by 
then, but there is no day in which I could have died, making us all 
effectively immortal.  So either we're missing something here, or something 
very bizarre is going on.

comments.author: Shawn Ravenfire

comments.text:
+Shawn Ravenfire You are confused. We are not discussing philosophy. We are 
discussing the quantum mechanical act of observation and its implications. 
Besides if you're only now understanding that we can never see ourselves be 
dead then you are clearly no philosopher...
comments.author: Googelplus Sucksys

comments.text:
+Googelplus Sucksys We're always observing ourselves, at least mentally 
(except, of course in a deep sleep in between dreams).  It's this 
self-observation which verifies our own existence.  Cognito ergo sum:  I 
think, therefore I am.

Of course, this raises an interesting philosophical question.  If you can 
be both alive and dead at the same time, and the dead you is not observing 
itself, but the live you IS observing itself, then by default, you will 
always be alive from your own point of view, and only appear to be dead 
from someone else's point of view.  Just a little thought experiment I came 
up with a while back.  Food for thought, anyway.
comments.author: Shawn Ravenfire

comments.author: Paul Frank

comments.text:
Text revised after I eventually traced the origins of the idea:

The need for a conscious observer seems to have been bolted on in the 1960s 
by John von Neumann and Eugene Wigner and this variant is termed the Von 
Neumann-Wigner interpretation.

It is not a necessary component of the Copenhagen interpretation itself. 
That merely involves an interaction between a closed quantum system and the 
rest of the world resulting in an observable state. It doesn't require the 
"observer" to be conscious.
comments.author: Alan Levy

comments.text:
+Alan Levy If I am understanding you the fact that there was a sentient 
observer did not make a difference in the experiment's results?
comments.author: Paul Frank

comments.text:
+Paul Frank what I think you are referring to is known as the Copenhagen 
interpretation. It says that the experiment doesn't have any defined result 
at all until it is observed, ultimately by a conscious observer. This 
brings us back to the cat which is both dead and alive until the box is 
opened. Schrödinger originally suggested this as a way of demonstrating the 
absurdity of the Copenhagen interpretation. 

The term interpretation is used because it's just one way of interpreting 
the behaviour of quantum physics and at the time nobody could come up with 
a better one.

In fact there is at least one other interpretation that was rejected back 
then due to a mistake in a calculation that has since been corrected. 
There's no possible experiment that could distinguish between the 
interpretations so you pays your money and you takes your choice.
comments.author: Alan Levy

comments.text: lol
comments.author: Dyson Lee

comments.text:
Thanks you very much +Richard Nick and +Alan Levy.  I appreciate your 
explanations.  What I have heard regarding the slit experiment is that the 
result varies depending on whether or not there is an observer, something 
that very much challenges sensibilities.  The anomalous behavior has led 
some physicists (Max Planck?) to posit that at its most fundamental level 
matter is consciousness.  I don't know how badly I have butchered things.  
Any direction you gentlemen could provide would be welcome.

Cheers, Paul
comments.author: Paul Frank

comments.text:
+Paul Frank subatomic particles and photons (and actually also atoms and 
small groups of atoms) obey a completely different set of rules to the ones 
that apply to the larger scale structures with which we are familiar. 
There's no reason why those rules should have to make sense to us and it 
turns out they don't.

We can perform experiments that demonstrate this however (not the cat in 
the box though). For example the Young's slits experiment, which 
demonstrates that they behave either like waves or like particles depending 
on what you measure and how you measure it. These experiments consistently 
demonstrate the (to us) weird nature of quantum physics. It's real even if 
we struggle to get our heads around it.
comments.author: Alan Levy

comments.text:
The particle is not in two states at the same time, it just has a 
probability of being in either state, but you don't get to see the state 
till you measure it,  the key is Probability.
comments.author: Richard Nick

comments.text:
The short answer is science doesn't really know until they actually look at 
the particle, but the act of looking changes the properties of the 
particle. Subatomic physics is a strange, strange land.

comments.author: Paul Frank

comments.text:
The basic premise of it was to show the nature of subatomic particles, 
specifically how they can be in two opposing states at the same time, until 
it is viewed. The poor cat is placed in a box with a vial of poison gas. In 
theory, the cat inside the box is both dead and alive at the same time,
